channel.title: Specific JVM instance
channel.description: posted for abraham2119: I am making an application in C which is in the need of finding runescape's JVM instance's process id. I can get any java.exe process id, although I simply can't differentiate between runescape's VM instance and others. Any ideas on how to accomplish this?

item.title: Specific JVM instance
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

now that im unbanned, i can finally post for myself:

i was originally using a jmx approach, but now i see frank_'s is so much cleaner

Read full topic

Yes… hence why you call it from injected code.

item.title: Specific JVM instance
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

[quote=“xeez`, post:42, topic:292052”][quote author=oksuper_ link=topic=385888.msg2926023#msg2926023 date=1251002961]
s/frank_'s/the non-retarded/
[/quote]It is, in fact, hypocritical of you to be ranting at me for providing a solution that will take a few milliseconds more than frank_'s approach, seeing as you provided a solution which requires the use of far more resources, not to mention the fact that it does not even fit the OP’s problem.[/quote]

You don’t quite realize… ANYTHING. Far more resources… /facepalm. Doesn’t fit the OP’s problem… depends on what problem? My answer addressed this problem in the post I quoted:

... since you wouldn't be able to differentiate between runescape's and others due to the fact that applet's don't contain window-titles ...

To differentiate between the VMs, find the loader class, and do:

URL location = clazz.getProtectionDomain().getCodeSource().getLocation(); if (location.getHost().endsWith("runescape.com") && location.getFile().startsWith("runescape")) { .... }

except using JNI.

PS;

    JavaVM *vmBuf[256];
    jint nVMs;
    JNI_GetCreatedJavaVMs(vmBuf, 256, &nVMs);

Wait… is… is that C code? YES IT IS.

Read full topic

item.title: Specific JVM instance
item.dc:creator: @xeez xeez`
item.description:
@xeez wrote:

[quote=“oksuper_, post:39, topic:292052”][quote author=frank_ link=topic=385888.msg2925994#msg2925994 date=1251001804]

frank_, one can benefit from both. The attach API requires one to pass the process id as a parameter in order to retrieve its respective JVM. So basically, one can list all processes (via whatever method one wants) and look for processes that are named “java.exe” (or “java”, depending on which OS you are running), get their process id’s, iterate through them one by one in which, through each iteration, one can get the respective virtual machine, attach an agent that implements the [tt]java.lang.instrument.ClassFileTransformer[/tt] class, revise the bytecode for specific patterns, and done. You can also simply implement the [tt]java.lang.instrument.Instrumentation[/tt] class, and look for the class’ “code source”, as oksuper_ suggested.
[/quote]no… you can list VMs

frank_ darling please don’t help his thread live… just let him be wrong he’s only hurting himself.[/quote]It is not my thread, and I was never wrong. I just took the “long-way” seeing as I did not know there was a “short-way”, which was frank_'s approach.

Read full topic

frank_, one can benefit from both. The attach API requires one to pass the process id as a parameter in order to retrieve its respective JVM. So basically, one can list all processes (via whatever method one wants) and look for processes that are named “java.exe” (or “java”, depending on which OS you are running), get their process id’s, iterate through them one by one in which, through each iteration, one can get the respective virtual machine, attach an agent that implements the [tt]java.lang.instrument.ClassFileTransformer[/tt] class, revise the bytecode for specific patterns, and done. You can also simply implement the [tt]java.lang.instrument.Instrumentation[/tt] class, and look for the class’ “code source”, as oksuper_ suggested.
[/quote]no… you can list VMs[/quote]

frank_ darling please don’t help his thread live… just let him be wrong he’s only hurting himself.

Read full topic

So basically, one can list all processes (via whatever method one wants) and look for processes that are named “java.exe” (or “java”, depending on which OS you are running), get their process id’s, iterate through them one by one in which, through each iteration, one can get the respective virtual machine, attach an agent that implements the [tt]java.lang.instrument.ClassFileTransformer[/tt] class, revise the bytecode for specific patterns, and done. You can also simply implement the [tt]java.lang.instrument.Instrumentation[/tt] class, and look for the class’ “code source”, as oksuper_ suggested.[/quote]no… you can list VMs

item.title: Specific JVM instance
item.dc:creator: @xeez xeez`
item.description:
@xeez wrote:

[quote=“oksuper_, post:36, topic:292052”]You don’t implement the Instrumentation class.[/quote]You are correct.

You can acquire an instance of the Instrumentation class*.
Implement agentmain(String, Instrumentation) to retrieve it.

Read full topic

item.title: Specific JVM instance
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

You don’t implement the Instrumentation class.

Read full topic

item.title: Specific JVM instance
item.dc:creator: @xeez xeez`
item.description:
@xeez wrote:

frank_, one can benefit from both. The attach API requires one to pass the process id as a parameter in order to retrieve its respective JVM. So basically, one can list all processes (via whatever method one wants) and look for processes that are named “java.exe” (or “java”, depending on which OS you are running), get their process id’s, iterate through them one by one in which, through each iteration, one can get the respective virtual machine, attach an agent that implements the [tt]java.lang.instrument.ClassFileTransformer[/tt] class, revise the bytecode for specific patterns, and done. You can also simply implement the [tt]java.lang.instrument.Instrumentation[/tt] class, and look for the class’ “code source”, as oksuper_ suggested.

Read full topic

item.title: Specific JVM instance

item.description:
@frank wrote:

i would be more inclined to use the attach api to find a java process than looking though a process list
